aroma of blue cheese, barnyard, sour beer, red fruits, grapefruit juice, the barnyard and cheese way less agresive than the lambic vinesomething i sampled earlier today.
very sour flavor, well balanced, i get sour, citrussy flavors, wild yeast. aftertaste is a bit less sour, ends dry.
quite to the point and very sour i miss some other flavors than just sour. perhaps lambic is just not me at this stage in my beer upbringing. comparing to others ive had, this one lacks breadth in the flavor mix. it is very sour very balanced but not much else.

750ml bottle 2006 vintage $32! It looks amazing, pink, red, cloudy with a puff of a pink head which fades to a ring of bubbles. It smells like musty lambic but not horsey, sour grapes,lemons, fantastic. It tastes like delicious sour grape juice, with a hint of must. The sourness is nice and the beer is really easy to drink.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-26-2008 05:13:45

750ml Bottle:  Aroma of tart fruit, oak, Brett, must, and wood.  Poured purple with a hint of ruby in color, and a small, white head that lasted around the edges.  Cloudy.  Not sparkling.  Flavor is very tart and lightly sweet.  Tastes of tart fruit, grapes, red wine, wood, oak, and bits of must and funk.  Light to medium body.  Dry, woody texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Tart, oak, fruit finish is dry.

This one pours a deep raspberry red color topped by a small white film with some spotty lacing around the glass. The aroma shows notes of tart merlot grapes, fresh berries, and some mild barnyard funk. The flavor shows more tart, red grapes and other berries to go with sours lemons, oak flavors, and some funky yeast. The flavors are tart, but not overly sour which reallys helps pull all the flavors together. The mouthfeel is light bodied and very carbonated and effervesent. This is a nice drinker with the tartness and berry sweetness blending well together on the finish. I need to try more Cantillons.
Bottle at the Woodshop Quad. Nose of funk and some  hop bitterness. Raspberry colored with a small pinkish head. Flavor is tartness, light bitterness and oak.

Dégusté avec french tickler, agaguk et parozoid le 21 janvier 2008.
Cloudy pinkish/red poor very thick looking with alomst zero head. Aromas are earthy, very complexe, rhubarb, red wine vinegar, celery salt, cumin, humidity, pommegranite and dandelions. Very acid and sour yet amazingly balanced for a lambic. Long lasting everything!Once the beer gets to room temperature it becomes slightly sweeter. Flavors are somewhat the same oas the aromas... added sour apples. After the acid /sour explosion i get hints of mixed nuts and ash. What an experience and amazing for its kind.

Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Hazy reddish body with a disappearing pink head. Aroma is acidic, barnyard and fruity. Flavor is sour, young fruit, wood and tart. The finish is long and acid. Delicious and relatively mild to be Cantillon.
Tasted at holiday tasting in ORlando.  Has a bright red koolaid color, but murky.  Very tart sour fruit smell.  Extremely Sour apple flavor...like drinking a green apple.  Pretty tasty

very good lambic, definitly unique but the geuze funkiness remains.  Very impressed with this and like it a lot.  pours a clear reddish purple pink.  funky aroma and dry pallate with a pure inviting finish.
rosso scarico schiuma media ma persistenza nulla il naso è vinoso un po di acidità legno in bocca uva asprigna piuttosto morbida finale un po legnoso

Bottle. Poured hazy purple color with minimal fizzy white head that diminished slowly with fair lacing. Good tart grape & yeasty aroma. Medium body with tingly texture and lively carbonation. Moderate to heavy sour fruity flavor with a solid tart fruit and small alcohol bite finish of moderate to long duration.

This is a standout lambic.

courtesy of tpd975.
Pours reddish with a quickly dissipating head.
Aroma is lughtly sour and vinegar with some oak - wood in teh nose.
Taste sour and yeasty with fruits that help the beer gain a very red wine like mouthfeel.
Not my favorite style, but the whole feel was really enjoyable.

rbesg07, bottle opened at west brewpub. a welcome relief from the west beers. clear pink, rose and rusty tea aroma, slightly cidery, hints of sherbet, not as intense as the other lambics sampled at west

Bottle courtesy of tpd975. Pours a still clear deep redish copper. Aroma is vinous with red wine vinegar, rotting citrus, spicy brett, and oak. Taste is the same as aroma. Medium thin mouthfeel with a mild amount of bitterness and moderate to strong amount of acidity. Very good.

Courtesy of the Otown December Tasting. Bottle. Pour was a nice light plum color. Aroma of soured red wine vinegar. Flavor was OMG!!! Sour sour sour. Honestly, it was over powering and so hard to detect other flavors. I definitely detected the wine, and some grapes, and that was about it. Not a fan of the sours. Sorry!!!
Altra straordinaria gueuze di Cantillon, non saprei come descriverla da quanto era buona; bottiglia da 75cl smezzata al Duca con Andre che è il miglior seguace del lambic.

Pours a hazy, deep brown burgundy colored beer, smallish bubbly white head with no retention or lacing
Funky horsey aroma, barnyard dominates. Strawberry, grape and sour cherry, and tannins from the barrels are noticeable. Huge barnyard funkiness, tartness and sourness up front, a little leather and oak, midpalate and the finish has fruitness all around, some red grape, strawberry, and sour cherry, lingering sourness and some tannic dryness on the finish with little to no alcohol detection. Light-to-medium bodied, moderate carbonation, dry on the palate.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 Pink color with scant pink head.  Aroma of strawberries, lemons and cherries.  Full mouth.  Sour and dry.  Good balance and complexity.

Second rating: tap at Churchkey.  Slightly less sourness, less dry, more vinous character.  Still nicely complex.  4.3

Tasting at Backus’ Backyard Bash. Thanks to the Cheeseman for the taste. Pours a bright strawberry red. Sour barnyard funk aroma, very pungent. Sour puckery taste with hints of tart apple and vinegar. Very dry sour aftertaste. Not a fan of this style, but this is well done.

Pours a cloudy garnet with a thin, wispy head that disappears in seconds. Cherries, grapes, oak, red wine, and vinegar on the nose. Sour grapes & cherries hit first, with oakiness and sweet fruit flavors following. Very rich & complex. Tart for sure, but not overpowering, with the sweeter side providing a nice balance. Finishes crisp & dry.

This is the kind of sour that American brewers are trying to emulate. Easily up there with the best.

Sampled @ Backus’s Backdoor Bash.Courtesy of the Cheeseman, Poured a beautiful pink grapefruit color with no head.The nose was full of funk.Flavor was sour but not overdone.Lots of vinous grapes here.This was pretty good considering i am not a big fan of sours.

I enjoyed this one with Beerlando and the pear and apple stilton.  Thanks to TheCheeseman for hooking us up with both.  It was amazing and my favorite experience of the BBBash.  It poured like a slightly milky, watered down pinot noir with no head but just a little white lacing.  Tastes like tart cranberries, wild yeast and a fine red wine.  Perfect balance between the tart, sweet and bold wine elements.  A great beer, especially paired with the sweet and creamy stilton.

2008 vintage, courtesy TheCheeseMan.  Wow!  This one is killer!  The color is so absolutely beautiful, like the flesh of a glistening, freshly sliced, ruby-red grapefruit.  The cloudy body is capped with a wispy white film.  Minimal, spotty lacing slowly rejoins the body.  The nose is mildly funky by Cantillon standards, fleshy Merlot and Cab Franc grapes taking top billing over tart red berries and dusty, barnyard yeast.  The flavor is supremely blended, no on element overpowering the next.  Luscious, lightly tannic red grapes show alongside old, saturated oak, tart berry, acidic lemon, and moderate barnyard yeast funk.  The mouthfeel is light and effervescent, sufficient tartness imparting a quenching sensation, with sufficient berry sweetness lending easy palatability.  This is just a damn fantastic beer.  Bravo Cantillon!  I might also point out that this beer paired like a dream with creamy Stilton with dried pears and apples, also provided by TheCheeseMan.  I need more of both, ASAP!

Bottle at Falling Rock Tap House, GABF 2008.  Pours ruby with an average, fizzy, white head, mostly lasting with good lacing.  Aroma is average malt (hay, straw), light hops (flowers), average yeast (earth) with notes of grape, wine, berry flesh and green leaves.  Light bodied, thin texture, average carbonation, and a sour finish.  Average duration, light sweetness, heavy acidity and sourness.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2012 Rerate now that I like sours. Nice ruby pour, whitish/pink head. Aroma is tart cherries, tart grapes, cheesy, yeasty, aspirin. Flavor is sour, grapes, funk, just amazing.

Pours out ruby pink with lots of bubbles.
Smell is fruity, musty, and funky. Taste is fruity and tart. With notes of cherry and grape with the wood. Almost a wine like after taste. Great sour finish.

Pours a ruby color with a white head that dissolves leaving just a white bubbling ring around the edges.  Even though this was aged in wine barrels I am getting a lot of cherry in the aroma... it almost reminds me of black cherry Kool-Aid, of course a little more sour and funky... a good amount of hay and barnyard aroma.  Flavor is really well rounded... just perfect in the sourness, tastes more earthy than other lambics I’ve had recently.  The wine really comes out in the flavor, very wine-like finish that lingers long after the mouth shock from the sourness fades.  I really think this is one of my favorites... awesome.  =)

750ml bottle with no date on it.  Pours a beautiful rosy pink color that looks a bright red in the glass.  A bubbly white head forms and actually has decent retention, certainly some of the best I’ve seen in the style.  A thick circle of puffy white bubbles circles the glass and some swirls form patterns in the center.  Aroma is bursting with Cantillon house character, strong as ever.  Intense Gueuze-like aromas - cider and horse, intense barnyard, very musty.  Some grape and cherry-like aromas are also noted as well as a flowery, perfume character.  A lot of acidic notes are also found. A tannic oakiness is found at warmer temperatures though it is certainly not overwhelming or obvious. This is just a lovely, intensely funky nose.  Flavor is fairly intense sourness that leads to a fruity, wine drenched finish.  The tartness does not linger, it hits the tongue then transforms to fruit and the finish is dry and not at all sour.  Very fruity with an assortment of berry flavors, acidity is low-to medium. Slight oakiness and wine-like in the taste as well. The flavor lacks a little something, I don’t know what, but the aroma is better than the taste.  If this tasted as good as it smelled it would be one of the better examples in its style but it’s missing a bit of complexity in flavor or something.  This is still nice though.

A murky beer with a rose colour. Aroma os fresh and with intense, dirty and musty notes. Otherwise the fruity notes from the grapes. The taste is very fruitful with heaps of grapes - the merlot really shows through! It ends sour and cleansing. Great beer!

330 ml bottle. Pours a beautiful ruby red color, much like a pinot noir aside from the off-white head. Sour fruity aroma. The taste follows the aroma, with some aromatics reminscent of white wine. Different and good.

Smells of two week old ribena... that’s been in the sun... rubbish. Might be 30% and capable of flooring you in a pint... i don’t care... beer should not be made of grapes... end of. - Emily (self confessed non-beer aficionado... sorry.)
Bottle, 2005 vintage. Clear reddish brown/pink with a little white head. Vinous aromas with notes of flowers, fruit and some mushrooms. Flavours of sour fruit, raspberries and oak.

Stunning luminous plum skin red, abundant fine pink head. That’s pretty! Dry wooly cinnamon, candied apples, salty dessert-island driftwood. Restrained mineral sourness with elements of green apples, raspberries and grapeskin. Refreshingly delicate but with a nice fullness. Beautiful.

2003 Vintage.  Tasted September 7, 2008.  Dark, murky red color with no head.  Aroma of grape vines.  Strong sour and tart wheat flavor.  Very little grape flavor, but a lot of what I would call leafy or vine-like flavors.  It seems that instead of the grapes imparting their flavors, it was aged with the vines stalks.  Still good, but not the ’wow’ I was hoping for.

Oh what a stunning beer. If I could give a perfect score for any of the categories (I am anal about that and have never done it), aroma and flavor would be 10 and 10 respectively. Aroma was perfect. Strong funk, mold and barnyard fill the nose. Smells like it’s been buried for 100 years in a dirty wet dusty blanket. Pour was a beautiful dark red/purple with no head. Taste was extremely sour and funky. Heavy sour grape with an acidic mouth puckering aftettaste. Dries the mouth and cheeks. Little carbonation that disappears mid drink. Near perfect.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Ruby red body and a whispy white head.  A strong funky aroma hits right up front, kind of horsey, like a barnyard, and a nice sour fruit note comes through.  The flavor is sweet and tart, plenty of delicious fruit presence, a bit of bitter funk, like cheese rind, comes through toward the finish.

Bottle 75cl.Light unclear medium red color with a virtually none appearance, virtually none lancing, head. Aroma is grape sour - acidic, vinous, tart. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and acidic with a long duration, and a dry tart finish. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. ;o)) (250508)

750 courtesy of Josh from Vintage Estates.  Pours purple/red with no head.  Nose is sour grape with a citrusy hint, slight oak.  Taste is an abundance of sour grapes, citrus, and lots more grape.  Dry and sour.  Did I mention that it’s slightly tart?  Also some slight, bright cherry notes, also some slight bready yeast and sourdough undertones as it warms.  Very nice beer.  Tasty.  Glad to have tried it.  Thanks, Josh.
Bottle @ Ølbaren. Medium red with small pink head. Fruity aroma. Very nice tart grape flavour. Excellent.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 750, cap and cork - Oct. 26, 2006 on the bottle.  Pretty ugly looking beer - murky pureed berry color with an almost white, light pink head.  Nose is wild and sour - bready and funky.  The oak is a nice complement but I dont get anything vinous on the nose.  Mostly sour, not very subtle, but intriguing.  Flavor is better - huge sour punch up front with a rounded fruit and wine middle.  Soft for a split second and then pile-driving sourness.  Earthy and supple finish with nice mineral qualities.  Not overly pithy - its the kind of lambic that makes your mouth really water as you sip it.  Excellent tiny bubbles and silky mouthfeel, dusty finish.  Nicely done.

Champange Bottle 75 cl. Pours a red/light brown with a tiny white head.. The aroma is outstanding, rather sour but full of strawberries mingled with all kinds of berries. The taste is very sour in the beginning but is fading out to be sweet/sour like a red grapefruite with notes of almonds and you sense the oakbarrels. Compared to other Lambics this one hasn´t got that buttery (oily)sidetaste and feeling.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2009 Draught @ Ebenezers. Beauitful clear red, almost no head. Aroma is slightly tart, sweetly vinous, red grapes. Hint of vinegar. Taste begins with tart vinegar, finishes with a quick snap of tartness followed by a lingering vinous red wine. Quite carbonated, with a nice light body. Fruity, beautiful.
UPDATED: JAN 29, 2014 75cl, exclusive brew with blue grapes, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex brew, balanced, cloudy, nearly no head, very good sour brew, yet expensive, a topper!
Bottle. Frothy white fair mostly deminishing head. Red colour. Exstremely sour aroma and flavor. Fruity (grape) notes. Not sweet. Average finish. Oily palate. Not very good.

On tap at Belmont Station puckerfest. Pours darker red with a soft white/pink head that falls fast. This had a quick touch of sweetness, more so than any other Cantillon I can think of at the moment, red grape lends a nice taste leading into the sour and acidic finish. Woody and dry finish with a sourness that is fairly mild for Cantillon.

On tap at Belmont Station’s Puckerfest 2008--$8 for 25 cl, but kind of worth it--Poured a hazy magenta body with a small fizzy pink head.  Taste of sour cherries and grapes that burst up the nose.  Acidic with a nice body and great mouthfeel.  Another terrific sour from Cantillon.

Bottle. Lovely reddish white thick rocky head. Fair display of lacework. Pale reddish Merlot grape color. Aroma was grapes, wood, horse blanket, mild fruit, quite vinous over the palate. Medium to full bodied with an average carbonation and very dry texture. Moderated to heavy acidic with good counter sweetness. Lingering grape and sour ending. Very nice!
Bottle. Hazy reddish colour with a medium slightly pinkish head. Rich arom and taste of classic lambic with sweet fruity notes. sweeter than expected, but still a very good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2010 Bottle at Ealing Beer Festival 2008.  Thanks to Maria/Renffisch for this one.  Hazy raspberry colour with thin pink head.  Lambic farmyard aroma, some red wine grape.  I mean I try to like Cantillon beers, but they are just too acidic, very good lemon and some red wine cherry fruit flavuor, but too acidic.  Does have nice cherry aftertaste though and extraordinary farmyard/acidity. 3.3/5.0   Re-rate at the new Moeder Lambic.  Hazy deep red.  Very red wine grape on aroma.  Lovely fruit in mouth.  Lovely linger on finish, really good red wine finish.  Lovely.

Bottle shared by Crosling, thanks Nick.  Poured a pink-grape color with a moderate pink-tinted head that faded to a ring.  Aroma of sweet grapes, light berry, tart funk, and some moderate yeastiness.  Smooth, lightly tart entry with undertones of grape and tart berries leads into a more funky sourness with some dry yeast character on the finish.  Pretty nice.
Vwery Lovely Lambic Indeed. Not too tart or sour, and the aftertaste was like Concord grape juice versus a bourdeaux. Easily Drinkable.

On draft at Teresas Next Door.  Poured slightly hazy ruby red that appeared undercarbonated.  Nose was fruity and vinous.  Agree with others that it had the appearance of a wine.  Sweet, complex fruity flavor initially with a sour, acidic finish.

Thanks to turd for sharing this at the Carolina Gathering. Pours a bright red with a light pink head, very minimal. The nose is fruity, vinous, tart, earthy, spicy. The flavor is fruity, tart, vinous, oak and spice. The palate is carbonated and crisp. Finishes spicy.
Nice reddish colour. Merlot grape in the nose. Well balanced an suitable sour lambic.

Bottle shared by the mighty TurdFerguson in his beer-heavy lair at the C.C. drink-down. Wow, now this is what its about. Blended version of this awesomely dry beer, which was a real treat. A pale rose color, crisp and lively just to look at much less to drink. Theres a modest and subtle nose, with dry grapes and lovely oak in the aroma. Active and quite present mouthfeel, dancing on the tongue. The finish is just ridiculously long and dry, with mild funk and ripe fruits everywhere. Superb.

Yesterday from bottle 75 cl. @ Weekend Sp. Ferm.
Hazy, dark (ruby) red color (like wine) with liittle pinkish head. 
Aroma sour raspberries, malts.
Medium body. Taste nice, some sweetness, fruit, bit sour.
Good.

2006, 75 cl, bottle. Looks like the swedish soft drink hallonsoda - reddish with white head. Aroma is lambic-ish - some funky notes of barnyard and sweaty horse - but here the funky notes are balanced with some nice fruits and a hint od red wine. Flavour is sour - squeezed lemons - with some funkiness and some harshness from the grape skins and seeds. Somewhere deep inside you can feel a hint of sweetness as well. The finish is dry with notes of grapes and red wine and a hint of bitterness. I really liked this lambic - the tartness is extremely mouthwatering! Great stuff!

#800

Bottled Oct 25th 2006. Pours out a light ruby color with a light pink almost whit head. Aroma is vinous with some grape notes. Taste is very well balanced, sour vinous notes throughout some nice tart grape flavors and some funk going on in there too. Pricey bottle and pretty much worth it.
beautiful red appearance with white head.  flavor is classic sour lambic but red grape sweetness quells the sourness and provides some smoothness at the end.  great

4-5-08 bottle shared at tasting 
Very red in color with a decent head and good sticky lacing.  Smell is big fruit and some funk too.  Good flavor of fruit are there.  The tartness is very nice.  Nice palate.  However, I perhaps started to have an allergic reaction to this as my throat started to slightly close up - so I didnt get a very large sample of this.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 37.5 cL bottle, cheers Jeppe. Pours hazy maber/redish with a fizzy and quickly disappearing pink head. Acidic dry brett aroma with a tart fruit note. Dry woody flavour with a nice grape flavour and very wineous notes. Light acidic dry flavour following. Shivering citric dry finish. Lovely! Very nice fruity lambic, classic Cantillon with a refreshing grape flavour.

Bottle courtesy of Dewbrewer, I believe.  Thank you!!


Pours like a cranberry spritzer with transluscency and a bubbly appearance.  Smell is fruity, sour and acidic and slightly funky and sweaty.
Taste is very fruity with some grapes, and red fruit like notes.  Tart grape, and cranberry come to mind.  Smooth and lightly thin in the middle and finishes dry.  Carbonation is light but sufficient.  Very unique and enjoyable.

tap at the Maproom. Didnt really like it, and I like wine! This tasted like if someone mixed a light carbonated beer with some cheap red wine. Dark red color(wine like) no head. Taste like a cabernet. Easy to drink but just not something I would consider a good beer. Sorry!

Pours brightly and vibrant; kind of an electric orange-pink color.  Heavily hazed.  Huge stinky cheese, mold, and wet concrete aroma; tannic, soiled, dirty, juicy.  Cinnamon, green apple, balsamic, pears.  Definitively funky and bracingly violent.  Flavor is a crisp, sour spiciness of raw wood mingled with aged balsamic vinegar and caramelized pear skins.  Crushing.  Searing raspberry acidity and stone ground brown mustard.  Bit of stale wood chip, musty carpet and mildew, and wet grass in the mid palate; mouthfeel is generous and velvety, with a soft sparkle.  The finish is simply stunning; a furious tide of raspberry and lemon juice leaving a coating of dry, burgundy infused irish cheddar.  Acidity predominates, and doesnt dry out to much; more of a dusty, cobwebby, soft merlot tannic bitterness.  Pineapple rind.  I needed a nice, soft cheese to cut through this a bit and didnt have one.  Truly great, and always intriguing.

Bottle picked up at Dranken Geers, Gent, Belgium and consumed at Lozs parents 03-04-08   Pours looking like a slightly watered down rhesus negative blood sample, although I dont suppose many bloods would have quite such a fluffy pink barbie head and be quite so fizzy. If I was a vampire this beer would look appealing, Im not but hey it still looked quite a tasty number. Starts off with a funky red or rose? wine on the nose. Tastes funky, tangy, tingly and not as sharp as many other Cantillons but bloody good (if youll pardon the unintended pun) This cut through ny smoked mackerel pate very nicely indeed, not overly sour , some nice dryness and a touch of wood, very nice indeed.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2009 On tap at the map room, chicago.  Hazy, ruby red color with light pink head.  Aroma is slight sour raspberries, grapes, medium sweetness.  Flavor is quite nice bold fruit, with subtle sour/tartness, medium acidity, nice.  Medium and well carbonated body.  I expected something a lot huger but was still pleasantly surprised at how easily drinkable this was. 8 4 8 3 17 = 4
--

Rerate, thanks to 17th floor for sharing.  05 vintage.  Cloudy dark red with small white almost pink head.  Aroma is stinky cheese with sour, big barnyard, some lacto, winey, dry sour red fruit, dirty.  Sour, wine flavor with tart, a little vinegar but sweeter, than that, moldy funk, big lacto component, woddy makes you wanting for more.  Medium and surprisingly active carbonation.  So tasty and woddy, big barrel but complex.  Really solid all around.

UPDATED: MAY 23, 2015 Re-rate 4/27/15: Bottle at Mikkeller Bar in Copenhagen. 2005 bottle. Lovely, funky, grapes, oak. 8/4/8/4/16=4

Re-rate 8/8/12: Bottle sample at a tasting at Idos place. Thanks zvikar. Deep red color with a pinkish head. Great barnyard aroma with nice grape fruitiness and a bit of citrus. Sour bretty flavor with some oak, cobwebs and lovely fruitines. Medium-bodied, rounded mouthfeel. Great. 8/4/8/4/16=4

(2/26/08) Bottle at Delirium Cafe in Brussels.  Hazy red with a quickly-disappearing white head. Acidic aroma with some sweetish fruitiness, grapes and some vinous character hints. Great sour flavor with citric fruitiness as well as some later notes of the Merlot grapes. A totally dry finish. Medium-bodied. 8/3/8/3/16=3.8

Bottle, bought @ SuperBest, Christiansfeld.
Pours a little muddy, deeb red-brown with a small, creamy film head. Aroma is acidic, with grapes, light cherries, apples and oak. Low carbonation, rather creamy and gets quite sticky. Flavour begins quite harsh, then turns softer with lots of wood, sweet fruits on top of the well-balanced dry tartness. Some caramel in the aftertaste.
Brownish red with a pink head. Acid and sour aroma with notes of grapes. The flavour is sour, but nicely balanced with a berrylike sweetness. Its very vineous and complex. I liked it very much!

On tap @ maproom. pours a lovely still cranberry color with the faintist of pink heads quickly vanishing to the thinest white string of bubbles around the glass. Nose is understated, faint wine cranberry tart aroma, berry aroma gradually grows as it warms. Flavor is distinctly Cantillon with pleasant vinegar tartness and clean flavors of cranberry more than wine grape. Finish is lingering fruit skin (grape, cranberry, plum) with a tannic dryness characteristic of these flavors. There is a mild berry sweetness to the middle , though still that of unripened fruit. As it warms flavors become more brightly berry with some interesting spice notes. Body is nice and vinous. Quite delicious.

Aroma was at first of black currents, dry, with some rustic somewhat mold like lemony, bretty lambic funk.  poured a medium purple color with a small light purple head and many tiny bubbles.  Flavor grow more intensly of lambic as it warmed.  Flavor started as black currents, with hints of lemon, and moderately sour.  Bright citrus flavors grow towards the bottom of the glass into a nicely sour lambic, with some blackberry.  Very soft palate.  Another pleasure to drink from Cantillon.

Pours a cloudy light purplish red color with foamy white head.  Sour earthy aroma with a lot of berry and grape.  Intensely sour/tart at first with a beautifuly balanced by the sweet grape and berry flavor.  Puckering but not too acidic.  Very refreshing and excellent tasting lambic.

750 ml bottle. Hazy deep red colour. Medium-sized white fince-laced head. Acidic, but mellow red berries aroma. Sharp for sure, but still nicely balanced. Low carbonation, but very refreshing. Sour and tart flavours and a little fruit. Long-lasting sourness with little fruit in the finish, mostly acid.

Bottle (Cantillon, Brussels)
Rich red, small pink head. Musty aroma, and a crotchy acrid sourness. Sticky bitter sour mouthtaste initially, but that transitions to a lighter elderflower and fruity body. Long dry bitter finish. A tad winey, and also bitter for me, and didnt have the level of mellowness I expected from the oak barrel aging.

On tap at Map Rom- Chicago.  Appearance is a little light-- looks like wine.  I prefer something a touch darker and richer.  Aroma and palate are almost pure wine.  Its good-- but tastes like a barrel aged wine.  I like Grand Cru, but this is a bit too winey for my tastes.

draught Gastropub Tuulensuu Tampere
Colour deep red fizzy , refreshinf sour grapes, aftertaste middle
Bottle @ Ølbaren, Cph. Pours a nice red-brown colour. Aroma is sour and fruity. The flavour is sweet and quite sour with a nice fruitiness. Long lasting good sour fruity finish. Nice!

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2009 A great drink.  Color is eye-catching like guava juice.  The aroma and flavor are wonderful and varied - anything from orange/tangerine to zinfandel pops up in the course of finishing a bottle, and they are all correct.  The burgundy barrel really helps this mellow out.

Bière de couleur framboise, avec un col beige tirant sur le rosé. Léger voile et beaucoup deffervescence. Belle bière. Le nez est sûr et amer, avec de fortes notes de raisins et de fruits rouges : cerises, cerisettes, framboise. Je lai ouverte pour un souper entre amis, juste avant la première gorgée, jai dit à lun des convives de ne pas être surpris, car les lambics sont surets. À sa première gorgée, il a sursauté, les yeux ronds, tentant de garder le tout en bouche! Je nai pas été aussi surpris, mais par pour autant ravi. La bière est très amère, très sûre, très et trop. Il ny a quun léger goût de raisins et de bière qui agonise derrière une nature définitivement trop brute. Peut être une bière pour les puristes ou les connaisseurs (dont je ne fais pas partie), mais pour lapprécier il faut trop souffrir à mon avis. Cest la seconde bière belge bien cotée que je verse dans lévier en une semaine, soit jai eu la malchance de tomber sur deux bouteilles tournées, soit je ne suis pas fait pour maventurer sur tous les sentiers!!

75cl bottle: Pours a lovely translucent dark pink, like blood-orange juice. Slight pink mousse dissipates before you notice it. What a lovely aroma wafts from the glass. An earthy bouquet of mixed berries, possibly grape, but more blueberry and raspberry. Acid followed by classic "horse blanket" with musty wood, and just a hint of cork. Wow, mild for a lambic and amazingly well balanced. A lovely play between dark red berries, cherry, grape, wood, acid twang, and light carbonation. A little sweeter than expected but that plays well with everything thats going on. Long dry, tart finish that leaves just enough fruit on the palate. Very enjoyable. I shared it with some "wine friends" and some "non-drinkers" and it went over very well indeed.

Cloudy pinkish/red poor very thick looking with alomst zero head.  Aromas are earthy, very complexe, rhubarb, red wine vinegar, celery salt, cumin, humidity, pommegranite and dandelions.  Very acid and sour yet amazingly balanced for a lambic.  Long lasting everything!Once the beer gets to room temperature it becomes slightly sweeter.  Flavors are somewhat the same oas the aromas... added sour apples.  After the acid /sour explosion i get hints of mixed nuts and ash.  What an experience and amazing for its kind.

(tasted at the Cellars after-tasting) Pours cloudy red with a white head.  Aroma smells just like the cow barns at a county fair.  Basically what Im trying to say is it smells like cow manure.  Theres funk there too, but this smells like any other high-end lambic maybe a little stronger.  Taste had all of your typical lambic qualities, sour, tart apple, little bit of cherry and thats about it.  Lingering sour aftertaste.  Not bad, but not my favorite style.
Bottle. Thanks to ekstedt. Reddish pink with a light, white head. Smell of gastric acid, grapes, sulphur. Intensely sour, very dry.

Courtesy of Pailhead. July 06. Bright red, chill haze, no head. Huge sour/tart kick up front, mouth puckering w/o taking a sip. Tart grapes and huge woody tannins in the background. Flavor again, very sour up front, faint grape and lacto. Through the middle develops a nice balance of sour/tart/wood tannin. Sort of 1 dimensional in a way, but I like it.

Pours an amazing deep pink-red, with a very mild head on top. Nose is quite sour, a little sweet fruit too. Taste is similar; this beer is incredibly sour, a hint of sweet raspberry deliciousness as well, but overall a quite not-sweet beer.

Stunning deep red look with an almost pink head. Aroma is heavy eartheren dusty along with sour rubberlike wild fermentation and minor sweet almost cherry like fruitness. Heavy sour flavor towards tart, with only minor notes of fruity grapes. Is acctually very simular to the vignerone imo. I still enjoyed the entire bottle though.

[Bottle] Pours hazy red with no head. Aroma is very funky, quite tart, and then grapes. Taste is is the same with the sourness coming through more as expected. Finish is a bit dry. An enjoyable beer, but it really didnt separate itself from other fruit lambics Ive had.

The color is like raspberry juice and the head is nice and pink. The aroma has notes of barnyard, sweat, basement and wine. The flavour has notes of moderately sour grapes, sweat and basement. Im not fond of this style. 2406

Small serving during 11-30-07 tasting at the Lex-Larp Cellars as I joined joet and the Twin Cities crew. Poured from a 750 mL bottle. Strong, funky smell that reminds me of cow manure or baby poop. I did get used to it after several sips, but Im not going to pretend I like it. If it hadnt become significantly less bad upon sipping, I might have given the aroma a 1. Here at RateBeer, we rate on a hedonistic scale, and the aroma by no means brought me pleasure. I dont care if thats what its supposed to smell like; it smells horrible. Pours a hazy red with a pink-hued light-colored head. Sour, dry, tart taste with some subdued sweetness. Flavors of crabapple, apple, lemon, and tonic water. Long, strong, tart aftertaste. Medium body. Soft in the palate. The rest of the beer more than makes up for the awful reek. If you try this beer, I highly recommend plugging your nose.

Sampled at Cellars in St. Paul, MN.  Thanks Brewfiend for opening this before I had to leave!  Milkman Dan warned us that this beer smelled like Cow Manure, but tasted heavenly.  I must admit, it has a weird aroma that I dont particularly care for, although I dont think its as bad as my sons dirty diapers.  Pink color with some carbonation.  Flavor is somewhat tart and winelike with some oakiness and some berry flavors.  As with most lambics, the sour seems to overtake the flavor, so I just dont understand why many consider this to be great.  I would agree with good, but not great.  I think I preferred the faro (Chapeau) over this.  Oh well.

Sampled at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a hazy bluish red amber brew with a fizzy light pink head that has good retention. Aroma of spritzy red grapes, oak, tart raisin, and more barnyard funk. taste is spritzy, medium bodied, with a sour red grape and pitted dark berry flavor. Finish is slightly dry with a lingering tart grape aftertaste. Quite the fruit lambic.

Cantillon Friday Night Tasting Session, Providence RI

Pours a red plum colour and light pink coloured head. Nose of grapes, red wine, wood, and acidity. Initial taste of red wine, vinous fruits and a fizzy mouthfeel. Wood is apparent when moving into the finish. Sourness lingers for an excellent duration. Finishing dry which didnt draw away from the duration. Very drinkable.
Deep red, very sour aroma of red grapes, oak, obv vinegary. Very dry finish after a sour vinous refreshing flavour.

Clear deep red in colour, light initially large pink coloured head, quickly dissipating, no lacing.  The aroma is very sour and acidic, tart grape skins, vinous, bretty, woody.  The flavour is of red wine, very tart and acidic, quite fruity, prickly, woody.  Sour mouthfeel, medium/light body, medium/high carbonation.  Finishes long, acidic and quite dry.  Instant heartburn.  Absolutely fantastic.  Very sour, seems to linger forever.
750ml bottle from the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/new-york target=blank>Premier Gourmet in Buffalo, New York.
Purchased in November 2004 and opened on September 30, 2007.
Vintage 2002.

750. Thanks, HogFodder! Pours deep pinkish purple with a thinnish, pinkish head. Gives off huge aroma of strawberries and moss. Thick, tightly bubbled attack. Refreshing for all the weight it packs. Dense lemon, strawberry, moss, and caramely tang feel to the mid-palate. Long, clingy sour finish.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2007 Deep red with smal pink head. Sour,  grapy and very vinious aroma. Flavor is sour, vinious and woody. Grapes are present. Reminds me of red wine. 

Rerate 24/11/2007 
Pours dark red with tiny pink head. Tarty aroma with plenty of grapes. Flavor is sour, vinious, oaky and has perfect balance. Ends of with long lasting sourness.

Cloudy darkish pink color on the pour with minimal white fizzy head.  Nose of vinegar slightly with fruits big on grape.  Flavor is quite sour with a great grape flavor coming through past that sourness.  I realy enjoyed this brew it just didnt rate that high on some of the levels, but overall that 17 should give an idea where it rates on my list.

Off notes 4/2007. Cork reads "bottled 2005". 

Pours a slightly clouded ruby with a pinkish hue to it. Nose is the typical sour with slight wood attribute and a fairly firm antiseptic tone as well. I find the flavor a very smooth and traditional sour with the fruit influence. There are berries and a touch of wood on the flavor. It is extremely sour, but I still feel like it is well within acceptable limits as I am taking long swigs of this one. I cant help it. Feel is nice and thick on the liquid and slightly carbonated. Its nice and smooth going down. 

Overall this is fairly sour, as these guys always are. But I think it is extremely smooth and doesnt really carry any harsh characteristics at all. Quite easily this might be the easiest drinking lambic I have had to date. Well worth the price.

I had this on cask at Spuyten Duyvil 6/2007, and it was just as amazing.

750ml Bottle. Nice deep red with disappearing pale pink head. The aroma and taste is sour with cherries / grapes / berries coming through strong. The finish has a pleasant dryness coupled with it being a little tart. Overall complex but drinkable.
Bottle. Deep red, very clear. Sourish winey aroma, fruity with raspberry notes and some cherry. Very refreshing, tart finish, sparkling. I love the idea!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2007 750 ml bottle. A hazy deep red beer with a pink head that disappears very quickly. The aroma is sour with fruity notes (berries, grapes). The flavour is tart and refreshing with a woody notes and a sour finish. perhaps more drinkable than other Cantillons. Medium body, complex.

Date: 07/15/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting, O-Town Throwdown

cloudy red, fine beige head, 
strong musty earthy aroma with a tart essence, 
creamy body, 
lots of tart fruity character with an earthy muskyness, the fruit character keeps growing and keeps up with the tartness, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4

Bottle, head-to-head RBESG 07. Slightly reddier than the unblended, thin white head. Nose is sweet, slightly more balanced than the unblended, vinous and really packed with fruit. Mouth is grapey gueuze with some sweet acidic tones. Tartness towards the end is to die for. Superb.

Sampled during the First Annual Stone Sour Fest.  Pink pour with a smallish head.  Earthy and sour aromas.  Flavor was similar with a very acidic finish.  Raspberries on the flavor as well.  Very sweet and tart.  Pretty good.
Bottle bought at  the brewery. Lovely cloudy red with a thin head. Full fruitiness, lambic laced with grape juice. but the lambic dominates totally.
Sampled at the 1st annual Stone Sour Festival 2007. Very sour with some oak flavors.

UPDATED: AUG 10, 2008 Tap @ Ebenezer’s re-rate damn wowo

Bottle-4th brew of Stone 1st Annual Sour Festival, July 22nd 2007.  Shared this cool day very mellow day with bikesandbeer, wetherel, westsidethreat, padrefan, fordest, denverlogan and many others. Ive been wanting to try this for a long time, but never quite got up the nerve to pay the $40 usually charged for this bottle.  Glad to get a taster instead.  Pours almost purpley red, plum red with a little head composed of white islands and a ring.  The nose is funky, sour, grapey and as my pal westside threat said a little bit of diaper in there, either that or the wind caught some of the mulch in the stone world bistro.  The taste is sour tart, vinous, and grapey.  Very good and interesting, but certainly not quite as good as some hype might make it out to be.  Worthwhile to have and glad Ive had it.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2010 (Bottle) Pours hazy red to purple. Grapey, woody and vinous aroma with fruity undertones. Medium acidity nose. Sour, acid and vinous flavour with tones of grapes, fruits and citrus. Tart and dry typical Cantillon style but more balanced, with some sweetness, compared to some other beers from the brewery. Medium body.  8/4/8/4/14 Second try: (Bottle) Pours dark cloudy orange amber with small off-white head. The aroma is super barnyardy with notes of wet wood, old oak, horse blanket, spices and damp basement. Ripe grapes, wet leather and phenols in the undertones. The brett profile is probably the most complex ever. clear notes of citric-like lacto as well. The flavour is dry and medium to heavily acidic with almost no bitterness.Brett than lacto in good harmony. Barnyard, aggressive lemon, wet leather and earth. The mouthfeel is tart/astringent with near medium carbonation. Super tart citric finish. Juicy and flavourful. Near medium bodied. I love. Probably the best Lambic ever!

Tasted various times over the years, including at the Stone Sour fest.  Semi cloudy cherry red color.  This is like a big tart-sour fruit soup with truly fascinating and fun tart cherry and raspberry profile.  A little barnyard, wood, mixed other tart berries but very refreshing and tasty from first sip thru the finish.  One of my favorites of this Stone sour fest and from Cantillon.

Lambic with Red Wine Grapes tried at Stones 1st Annual sour beer tasting.  Wonderful raspbeer red color and sour cherry flavor and aroma.  No head, but still has slight carbonation when tasted.  Slight nice funk in the aroma.  Great beer.  Aroma gets better as you approach the bottom of the glass.  Delicious.

Small pinkish white head. Hazy pale crimson body. Metallic grainy sour aroma with papery notes. Metallic bitter lambik taste with intense barnyard character. Sharp, mouth-puckeringly sour. Faint sweetness towards the end. An experience, but not necessarily a pleasant one. (0.75l bottle, thanks to gr0ve.)

Bottle. Hazy and almost opaque, red color or almost orange, with some head. Lovely aroma of fruit, oak and a hint of the Merlot grapes. The grapes come out in the flavor, that combines both the typical sour lambic and red wine into a very refreshing beer. Its definitely not something you just drink quickly, instead enjoy it quietly as the beautiful summer day passes by.
Bottle. Red/pink color, small pinkish head. Sour, sourish aroma, fruity, rasp berries, grapes. Sour fruity flavor, fresh strawberry notes, raspberries. Quite balanced.

Bottle, 75cl: Hazy red colour,no head. Sparkling. Aroma of flowers,citrus, sweet, sourness.Nice complex mix here.
Flavor is almost the same,grassy were there to.Medium body, nice long fruity complex finish.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2014 Bottle, 75 cl. Ruby read and cloudy with some pink bubbles. Cidery aroma with raspberries and bloodgrapefruit. Medium bodied and a bit spritzy. Medium acidity.

Bottle.   Pours a cloudy dark rose-red color with a medium sized pink head.   Aroma is funk, cherries, vineous, oak.   Flavor is dark tart cherries, oak, grapes, barnyard, lemon.   Palate is medium light, medium to  high carbonaton, tart, dry finish.   This is a really fantastic brew.   Tons of tartness and refreshing acidic fruit flavors make this an excellent summer brew.   That being said, its way too pricey for me, glad I got to try it, but wont be doing it again any time soon.   I think their whole line up is fantastic, so you cant go wrong at any price point.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2007 Light ruby body with a very short-lived head.  Nose is woody and funky.  Taste is dry, very dry.  Supposedly aged with grapes in oak barrels, the barrels is a lot more predominant than the grapes.  All kinds of dry woods on the tongue.  The beer is indeed fruity but the flavour is not particularly focussed on grapes.  More of a general red fruits flavour (grapes, cherries, berries, etc.).  Some acidity but nowhere near the level of their Gueuze.  In this case it is the woody dryness and not the acidity that makes it a sipper.  I prefer their more standard and cheaper products but this is truly an excellent beer with its own personality.  Its only problem is its stiff price tag.  At only 5% it could be an everyday beer, but at $20/bottle ouch!  Its not that I would mind being poor as long as it doesnt prevent me from having a lot of money.

Aroma: wonderful, complex, rosen, perfume, malty, sourish, old, musty, rich, grapy, fine bath bombs, cherry sweetness, tulips.
Appearance: really dark cherry red with quickly fading pink foam. Very nice. Opaque.
Flavour: initially soft, grape flavour. Sexy sourishness, vague sweetness, well balanced & very elegant. Vinous, lactic aftertaste.
Palate: powerful but incredibly soft and smooth. Frighteningly smooth. Distinct but nice carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2007 Courtesy of Joebrew.  The aroma has cherry, and lots of it.  Considerable barnyard aroma.  Flavor has lots of cherry and light oak.  Raw grape flavor.  Acidic and sour, but the cherry is still there.  Bright, Burgundy color.

Thank to Joebrew for sharing.  Dark red pour iwth a delicious sour nose.  Dry body with hints of oak, cherry, grape, and barnyard.  Sourness almost had a lemon tinge to it for me.  A most excellent pour.

Bottled.  Poured medium rose with a very nice initial cap of light pink head.  Aroma was of soft vinous notes accenting some dusty barnyard funkage.. lemon and vinegar in there as well.  In the flavor, tart vinegar washed over the front of the tongue with wheat and lemon-accented dust across the middle.. hint of sweetness along with the tart, lemony-vinous finish.  The tartness was not too aggressive, and the overall balance was superb.. well-integrated barrel characteristics.  Great one!

Bottle. Hazy, orangey red with a light pinkish head that disappeared completely. Woody nose, lemony lambik in the background, just a hint of other fruit. Good lemony lambik flavours, fruit is more pronounced in the mouth and marries well with the lambik. The wood comes in especially towards the dry finish. Another great invention from Cantillon.

750ml bottle.  2006 bottle.  Aroma:  Very vinous with a strong dose of dry red grapes.  Nice sourness with a bit of red wine vinegar.  Dusty funk with some light cheese.  Oak comes out more as it warms. Appearance:  Pinkish-red in color and quite hazy.  Light pink head was small and rocky with good retention.  Fair lacing.   Flavor:  Very fruity with vinous grapes being the star.  Nice tart sourness.  Oak and funk hit me at the same time.  Funk is dusty/cobweb with a fairly strong cheesiness.  Dry finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium-high carbonation.  Overall:  Pricey but worth it.
A very tastfull grapebeer, made with red wine grapes (merlot and Cabernetfrancs). They added some liquer for fermatation on bottle. A scour and good tasting fruit beer

Bottle @ my brothers (Vac) & Abbys (zug4abby) house warming party. Ok you have to ready for this one. After being in San Diego for a few days and drinking IPAs and IIPAs one after another followed by a few big & impy stouts, I think Abby pulled this one out just to screw with my palate.  Poured a reddish brown with a thin pink head. The aroma found that lambic sour fruitiness. The flavor was tart to say the least with a fruit and light citrus blend. Medium body and tart aftertaste. Dont be scared of the sourness. Just be ready for it. Very decent overall!

Bottle, 75cl. Opaque red/purple colour with a small pink head. Aroma of wood, raspberries, cherries, yeast and that delicious scent of lambic. Initially a fruity flavour, unripe berries and just very sour. It gets better after a few sips (when the taste buds go numb...) and release a more vinous flavour. Slightly creamy mouthfeel. Personally I would have liked a softer carbonation but this is definitely a great beer!
Hazy reddish color, short off-white head. Aroma is tart, fruity of cherries and grapes, some marzipan. Nice fruity taste, soft sweet and slight tart, some oak.
Fruity aroma of grapes, winey. Hazy, red coloured with not much head. Taste is tart, bit sweet, winey/fruity (grape), some oak/wood in it. Quite nice and refreshing after a load of imperial stout.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 2004 vintage. Pours a reddish pink with minimal head and carbonation. Sour grapes on the nose... more like a wine than a beer. Same for the flavor... sour with hints of grape-y sweetness.

Re-rate 5/24/2008. Damn... was I off base in my first review. Boatlaods of grape and wood tannen all over the place with that dirty, Cantillon house funk on the tongue. Acidic, tart and wonderful all around.

Pours a glowing purple, dark pinkish color with a very thin light purple head.  Lovely looking.  Smells of monster sourness with a very fruity background.  If I had no clue what was being poured blinfolded and smelled this beer, Id guess Cantillon.  The taste is very acidic, but not as overpowering as the aromas would suggest.  Once you get past the sourness, some nice atringent fruits show up.  Some grapes and lemon from the acidity are definitely present.  Just another good Cantillon showing.

I hope I enjoy this $30 beer.  750mL, Botteld in 2003 on the cork.  Pours a slightly hazy bright orange with some maraschino cherry colored highlights, and a small white head (tiny bubbles) that fades to a ring before long.  Smells really sour and acidic.  There is some woody oak, funk, faint grape juice.  Flavor is indeed quite sour--lemon and unripened granny smith apple-like--with some oak and funk again, and a dry finish.  Burped stale herbal hops.  Light body with minimal carbonation.  Very good.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle (from Bitter Virtue, bottled 04). Slight grape juice and musty caramelised sugars in the aroma. Slightly vinous.  Grape perhaps less noticeable than other fruits in cantillon beers. Sourness slightly restrained.
On draft at capones Pours a light red color with a nice pink head. Aroma of sourness, tart fruit, and some funk. Flavor is extremely tart and sour  with hints of oak. medium bodied with a dry finish.
Blackurrant red with off white head.  Sour typical cantillon aroma. Fruity fresh  (cranberry/cherry) vinegar. Very nice & almost easy drinkable (Never thought I should ever write that) Nice!

Bottle at C-bus 6 shared by sliffy, thanks! Murky melba color, a white head with pink accents. Sour and funk stand out in the aroma with some floral qualities as well. Flavor held some light vinous qualities along with oak, funk, and of course sour. Solid body, nice carbonation with a light bitter finish.

Tap at Ginger Man.  Deep ruby beer, with a thin white lace.  Almost still appearance.  The aroma shows the characteristic Cantillon house character but also an intense fruity pinot noir grapiness on top.  Strong malic/lactic tartness.  The acidity, while intense, is much more restrained than in many other Cantillons Ive had.  Warming brings up loads of sweet ripe fruit, cherry, red grapes, and a touch of raspberry.  Flavour is lovely, a soft sweetness on the front shows off the grape/cherry flavour while a soft tannic astringency helps balance this on the back.  Further warming brings up notes of earthiness and funkiness that Ive come to expect from Cantillon.  Once the beer is at room temperature, the fruity aspects really dominate, with the acid serving as a bit of punch to brighten them up.  Quite a treat finding this brew on tap.  Awesome stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 8, 2007 Tap at Ginger Man. Pours a beautiful red color, and you cannot see through it. The aroma is complex with lots of vinous qualities, hints of musty wood, aged cheese, light lemon notes, and even more I couldnt pick up fully. The flavor is clean with that traditional Cantillon crispness and acidity. Theres lots of vinous qualities with hints of oak, raspberry, lemon juice acidity and a crisp finish leaving you wanting more. Great stuff.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2007 On tap at Ginger Man. Fantastic stuff, as usual. The aroma was huge, funky, stinky cheese, ripe and sour, deep and complex with oak, peach, plum. Taste was big, sour, and ripe, but palate was a little thin, with very little carbonation. A bit lacking in body, but the flavor was delicious, earthy. Mmmmm. Fantastic!

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2007 Draft @ Capones.  Red color that makes it look like wine - Oaky, vinous aroma.  Taste is sweet & tart with a variety of earthy, oaky, and dark fruit flavors.  Simmers the palate - very unique and enjoyable!  The best lambic Ive had.

Red of color with slightly red head. A sour aroma with notes of berries and oak. The flavor is fruity with notes of oak. Nice flavor wich reminds me why gueze is so good, this is half wine and half gueze in my mouth. It tastes odd, but in the good way.
On draft at capones. Pours clear jolly rancher candy red with a decent size pink head. Aroma of mustiness, tart fruit, and oak. The flavor is fruity, tart, wood, yeasty, carbonated, but not bad.
Bottle. What a lambic tasting this then i know why i like this style of beer, it is so complex.
Clear cherry red color with slightly pink head. Really cherry and strawberry like taste. Lots of grape anr cranberry as well. Good solid sparkling cantillon!! One of my favorites.
Lovely deep ruby color, aroma of barnyard, sour cherries and berries. Very sour and musty with stronger berry than vinous flavor. Bubbly lambic makes my belly roil. Must eat cheese.

On tap at Capones.  Dense, day-glo burgundy.  No head, a few bubbles.  Ive never seen anything this color before, let alone food.  Sour, cherry-lemon nose.  Faint horse blanket.  Gets poopy after a few sips.  Quite a full body for a lambic.  Virtually no carb but the palate is still lively.  Starts tart, of course, but never jaw clenching.  Light cherry, lemon, red grape skins and lemon pith.  Airy cherry stone finish with hints of cinnamon.  Exotic, earthy and mouth watering.
Tap @ Capones.  weeare138s description is spot on and worth reading for a full and accurate account.

(Draught) Dark red colored, little pink head. Aroma is good with fine cherries and dry woods, strong crape-sourness there too. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor is also fine with cherries and refreshing carbonation, sourness of course dominates with some wooden tones.

Shared by Sliffy at the Columbus tasting#6 thanks Dan.Very nice sourness in the aroma.Pours a very murky melba with almost no head.Very nice balance of sourness and the oak flavors.It really mellows out the sourness.Medium mouthfeel with a very smooth sour finish.
Draft. Hazy red color. The funk flowed from the small wine glass it was served in. Sour with tart funk finish.

750ml bottle shared by sliffy at Columbus Tasting 6 - Pours strawberry shortcake red..  Looks like white zinfendel almost in the glass.  With a very slight offwhite head.  Aromas of rotten cheese, barnyard, and some vinegar.  Flavor is less sour than I anticipated though.  A good amount of cheese in the flavor too with barnyard and a lot of sour grapes.  Vinous is the word that best describes it.  Palate is quite acidic with a dry finish.

Bottle at C-Bus 6: This one hurt the bank account, but oh was it worth it. Pours a golden purple, with a white-pinkish head. Aroma, of grapes, some funk, and sourness. Flavor, dry grapes, a sharp tartness, and quite sour, vinous, with a soft sourness on the finish. Really nice and balanced though, really a great beer. Glad I splurged.

Shared by Sliffy at C-bus 6.  Dan knows I love a good lambic--and he picked a great one here.  Lovely light sour aroma with some hints of maple syrup actually--probably from the oak.  Looks like a hazy golden and red sunset.  Perfect palate for this style.  Great balance off the bat in the flavor department with a nice marriage of oak and sour flavors. Vinuous for sure, and not overpoweringly sour like some lambics can be.  One of the best Cantillons Ive had so far.

Bottle shared by Sliffy.  Thanks Dan!  I have tried so many times to like the lambics guezes and what not with no success.  This one actually was the first one that really wasnt too bad.  The smell was still skomething I could not get over.  Smells rotten!  The appearance is a nice muddled cloudy red with a lively cherry/white head.  The taste is what I liked on this beer.  It was very dry and refreshing with lots of tart sourness coming through but it wasnt overpowering.  I still dont think I will be buying any of these beers any time soon...or drinking lots of it, but this one wasnt too bad at all.

On tap at Capones in Norristown, PA, served in a small wine glass. Appearance was good but a little put-off by the cherry cough medicine color. Nose was exactly as expected, and hoped for! The musty aroma and somewhat tart taste combined well with each taste. This offering from Cantillon is probably the one that you need to enjoy with your nose as much as your tongue. Taste and mouthfeel are good throughout the sip; does not last long after you swallow except for a dry sweetness.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2007 On tap at Capones in Norristown. Considering I wrote the descriptions for the tap list last week, I should hope that people wont mind my notes looking similar to the brief descriptions seen in the restaurant. In any case...
Appears a ruby reddish toned pink with a small, bubbly head that quickly fades into nothing. No lacing is left and the spider legs are very faint when tilting the glass and brought back to center.
Smell is of tart, sweet raspberries, barnyard funk, rubber, wildness, light horseblanket, and oak.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with vinuous notes and oaky vanilla pushing through the raspberries and wild funk.
Mouthfeel is  medium bodied, vinuous, sweet & tart, dry, slightly acidic but mellow.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2008 Draft at Capones (Norristown, PA). Cloudy red with no head. Tart, earthy aroma, with a hint of red grape and malt. Very tart; again with notes of grape, complimented with wood, tannins, and pepper. Long, sharp, tart finish.

Draft at Capones. Poured a cloudy cherry red body with hardly any head. Aroma is of cherry, strawberry, yeast, and farmhouse. First sip is of cherry. Farmhouse, tart and slightly sweet with a small sour tone to it. Light sugar and smooth with a light sweet aftertaste.

Draft at Capones.  Ruby reddish color with aroma of funky horseblankety notes, some earthen malts, some grapes, and some aged cheddar.  Tastes extremely tart, as usual for these guys, with a lot of grape flavors coupled with funky cheesy earthy hints.  Lively on the palate, this one stays fruity and tart, with increasing funkiness as it warms.
Draft at Capones. Cloudy red color. Good lacing. Aroma is vinous, musty with some barnyard. Flavor is very vinous. Medium body. Funky good.

Draft, Maxs 3rd Annual Belgian Beer Festival.  Hazy, ruby-red color; white head with fine-bubbled lacing.  Funky, viscous nose; showing horseblanket and tart red fruits.  Medium-to-full, tart mouthfeel: tart cherries, horseblanket; plenty of funk and red fruits.  Medium, tart cherry and citrus finish.

Hazey, maroonish-red body with a small pink head. The flavor is horseblanket, cheese, very funky and raspberries. The flavor is raspberries, yogurt, lemon and lots of bright lactic acid. Medium body is soft and round with a long tart finish. Superb.

Bottle. Small and quickly disappearing pink head. Hazy dark red body.  Acidic fruity aroma. Flavor first sharp grapefruit later plums and raisin. Long and astonishingly sweet aftertaste. Pleasant surprise.

Very cloudy dark orage with a large head, good lacing and retention. Aroma is lemony with barnyard action, tartness, caramel, wood, some wine characteristis. Medium body with a tart finsih. Enjoyable with a huge complexity.

Saint Lamvinus had long lurked in the shadows of my cellar, creeping out of its lambic corner from time to time, titillating but never convincing as I remained impervious to its charm, waiting for time work its metamorphosing dexterity. Finally on a winter eve, it was uncorked and of its bright cardinal body spewed a bubbly white foam. Cherry appeared strongly upon the nose alongside Cantillons classic sourness and a woody complexity. Sweet tonalities of white wine, brown sugar and raisin accompanied the delicate balance of vanilla and raspberry, along with a slightly cheesy note. Flowing organically onto the palate, it seemed the nose was reflected with accented sourness, red currant, white pepper and the slightest hint of grape. The rubbery and somewhat unpleasant acerbity that I often associate with Cantillon was present again, which combined with the surprisingly minimal vinous aspect felt rather underwhelming. The long sticky and fruity sour aftertaste is vaguely redeeming but I found that I would much rather a simple bottle of Cantillons Kriek than go through the trouble of acquiring and caring for such an esoteric yet uninspiring bottle.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2008 on tap at maproom. pours red with almost no head. aroma is always tough to get at the smokey maproom but got some vinegar, grape, and some funk. taste is something special. pretty tart but not overly sour, has some mild very pleasant sweetness too, fruity notes of grapes, raspberries, and subtle sour cherries. also has some earthy and funk tones. finishes very dry. amazing stuff.4.2. 

2/19/07, on tap at the maproom. this is actually one of the more mellower (sour and acidity wise) cantillon. picked up a bighter winey grape sour nose this time thanks to the anti-smoking law.  the grapes and wine notes are integrated wonderfully. i could have used some more sourness because it tends to fall off the palate a little quick. still a wonderful fruit lambic but no blueberry cantillon. 4.1.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2007 [In the summerhouse of Fjerritslev after 180 km on bike in 2005.]

This brew was my very fist Cantillon and maybe it was also one of the first I could not drink totally finish. Now times has changed and Im sure that it will not happen today. But it was so sour that my nose almost turned 100 around  its own bone and with the hole family looking at me I had to swallow it, not to loose face. After two hours I only poured a little in the sink....and it was my most expensive beer until that. I have highrated it a little bit, because now Cantillon is one of my favorites. If I should drink it again it will be more than 4.0!!!

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2012 First rating(Bottle, looks about 75 cl, thanks omhper!) Bottled 2003. Shady redish brown color, small disapearing pink head. Lambic and gueuze acidic spontaneous fermented scent. Stables and grass. Grassy sour spritzy taste with a metallic aftertaste. Spritzy mouthfeel. Some bitter astringent mouth puckering feel, might be from the wine? Also some dry feeling, oak?8/3/8/3/16=3.8RerateBottled 2006 compared side by side with bottled 2007. 
Both on 75 cl bottles, both BB 12/2009.On March 16, 2009
2006 (Bottled 25 OCT 06) = Hazy grape color, smallish apricot to pink head. 
Sloe (blackthorn?), mild acidic, sweetened unripe (green) red currants scent. 
Sour, red berries, grape peel taste. Smooth mouthfeel, no bitterness. 
acidic and red berries aftertaste, also not ripe red currants.
7/4/8/4/16=3.9
2007 (Bottled 22 NOV 07) = Hazy grape red color, smallish pink head. 
Sour, acidic, automn forrest, fruity, red currant scent. 
acidic to sour, red currants when not quite ripe (green), lemon, some 
blueberry taste. 
Mix of smooth and spritzy mouthfeel. No bitternes I can sense. 
Acidic aftertaste. Very nice. 
8/4/8/4/17=4.1Rerate75 cl bottle thanks to Nisse666! Sampled on March 8, 2012Hazy inside of blueberry color, pink head. Grape, oak, sour scent. Sour, metallic, grape taste. Very sour aftertaste, and gut wrenching. Medium mouthfeel, very low bitterness.6/4/7/3/14=3.4Rerate75 cl bottle thanks to Clyx! Purchased in Denmark. Label statets 37.5 cl, guess they make mistakes? Cork printed with 2005, sampled on August 11, 2012Murky red color, pink head. Acidic, lactic, sour, funky, some berry scent. Acidic, sour, green apples, fruity, tart, biting on lemon taste. Mouthpuckering sour, dry mouthfeel, very low bitterness. Sour gut feeling.7/3/8/4/15=3.7

UPDATED: APR 7, 2008 Oh Yes. Pours Cabernet grapeskin red with deep pink accents. Typical small but long-lived Cantillon head(for an aged bottle), pink and purple with white ringlets of bubbles. Mostly translucent, slightly oily in appearance. Cantillon house aroma that seems more full bodied than usual. Strong musty grape aroma with a tannic flash and a bit of cedar. Reminds me of the Italian variety of goat cheese somewhat. The sourness penetrates my senses, and I have yet to taste this. Upon first sip my mouth comes instantly alive, like drinking lambic for the first time, all over again. Taste is much sweeter than any Cantillon Ive tried, excluding Rose de Gambrinus, but I believe its even a touch sweeter than even that beer. Flavor is magnificent, so well rounded and so delectable. The tartness melds perfectly with the sweetness. Cherries explode! Raspberries pummel! Grape skins entwine my taste buds and oaky tannins tie it all together. The tannic-style acidity lingers, sinking into my cheeks, the sides of my tongue go numb. Fire slowly cascades down the back of my throat. At first the finish seems very full bodied, then suddenly it becomes light and quenching. Simply marvelous.

Bottle. 2005 vintage, sampled on new-years 2006-7. So this bottle is almost at two years of age and I fear that the grape character might have diminished somewhat. Nonetheless, amazing lambic and more grape character than the Vigneronne.
Bottle, ruby pink with a huge foamy pinkish head. A subtle red wine aroma with a touch of tamarillo. Sour and tart with a long tart finish. Definitie red wine flavours with some tannin. Brilliant.
UPDATED: MAR 9, 2007 Bottle. Weird "cellar"-aroma, smoke and cigar. Sour, great taste with fresh lambic, wheat and grapes. Good.

Of all the beers on RateBeer, this St. Lamvinus is arguably the closest to wine.  And it tastes like it with a hint of grapiness imparted from the Burgundy barrels.  Very tart, though less so than Cantillons other lambics.  Pink in color. Complex.
Cork says 2004.  Pours ruby red into a tumbler.  Pink micro head quickly recedes to skim surface.  Red grape and funk aromas. Tart sulphur up front and crisp with a lasting sour burgundy finish.
Red with a pink head. Aroma full of berries and some champagne. Very dry, slightly bitter and a hint of oak.
Bottle at Horsens beerfestival. Red colour with a pink head. Aroma is fruit, yeast, sour. Flavour is fruit, yeast, sour.

From a 750mL Bottle.  Pours a rich, burgundy mahagony with a light layer of pinkish head.  Tart raspberry aromas mingle with sour pinot noir grapes and some soft oaky vanilla tones.  Crisp, sour mouthfeel with a prickling carbonation feel.  Loads of fresh, tart, under-ripe dark fruit flavors dance on the palate.  More tart berry flavors and some sour raspberry seeds tickle my tongue before finishing in a dry, woody smack.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2011 Bottled at Horsens Beerfestival. Clear, red beer with a pink head. Yeast, mould, sourness and berries in the aroma. Yeasty flavor with barnyard-notes. Astringent, thin body and a stinging finish. A nice, teeth-cleansing beer, but as usual with lambics I have troubles describing it, but really love it. Rating: 8-4-7-4-15-3.8. 061028Bottle, 375ml. A slightly hazy reddish beer with a creamy off-white head of moderate size. The aroma is unmistakable lambic but with a vinous touch without the alcohol. Lemon, funk and fruits in a lovely blend. Medium body, dry and puckering and lovely carbonated. Flavorwise its wonderful, sour and lemony, with unripe grapes, funky notes and cellary, barnyardish touch. More straightforward fruity than a pure lambic, yet not as fruity as a kriek or frambozen, still its lovely balanced. Damn, this is good, maybe it deserves a higher rating as well, but that would be unfair to some other lambics. Gimme more. 110122

BA BBF 06.  Dark amber with some ruby red hues.  Aroma:  pretty funky, fruity, all over the place and complex.  Taste is dark tart fruits, tartness, brett, lightly sour but not in that acetic acid (vinegar) way.  Excellent, pretty complex.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2012 Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is reddish dark amber. Aroma is fresh and citric. Taste is sweet with grapes but also has some acidity. Original rating Oct 28th 2006 6/2/6/2/11. Rerated May 16th 2012 8/3/9/4/18.

2005.  purple red colored with a small pink, purple head.  light sour grape aroma with hints of sulfur.  flavor is very woody, plastic, cork, bret, and funk.  not too fruity.  grapes show up more as it warms.  a little disappionted.

Draught at Maxs in Baltimore
Ruby blood color, light pink head. Nose of light grape, darker though with currant and cherry notes. Lightly vinous and tangy notes. The flavor is musky, a bit dry, but still very complex and tasty. Finishes ripe, juicy, clean. Good cantillon. I figure it must be better in bottles though.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2008 1/22/07 On tap at the maproom.  Deep red ruby color with a small pink head. A nose of sour grapes, sugar, and oak.  Lightly carbonated, nice mouthfeel. Sweet flavors balanced well with sourness.  Red grapes, tart, and so oaky.  Drying sourness.  Oaky tart finish.  Comparing this to the other vintages, the earthyness seems to really come out over time.  I love this beer. 9/5/8/4/18 = 4.4  
10/1/06 - 750 ml bottles.  Vertical with vintages 2005 and 2001.  Pours a bronze red with a small pink head.  The aroma comes out as woody and earthy with dark fruit and sour undertones.  The flavor hits the tongue tart and sharp but rounds out well with oaky earthy flavors that fade to delicate sweet grape fruitiness that finishes very long.  The 05 is similar but with the oaky and dark fruit notes turned down and a little thinner body.  This one blew me away.  4.7

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a hazy pinkish-red with a large light-pink head. Nice funky aroma of sour fruit. Flavour is sour and vinuous -- getting even more so as it sits, quite tasty and drinkable. Medium bodied. Very good, another winner from Cantillon.

Bottle shared with GregClow, Hogtown Harry, and Blankboy.  Deep red, small white head.  Wow - aroma is so strong - funkiest one yet tonight on a night of funky aromas!  Sourness, yet malt there too - someone at the table mentioned fruit skins, Ill go with that...Taste is very sour, lots of grape skins.  Big lingering sourness.  Thin but adequate mouthfeel.  A really nice lambic - and very drinkable.

Bottle shared with blankboy, tupalev & HogTownHarry - HogTownHarrys bottle. Hazy orange-pink colour, no head. Lovely mellow funk aroma with fruity wine notes. Flavour - dry, tart funkiness with notes of lemon juice, wine & horseblanket. Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2006 Not the best from this brewery.  Poured a ruby color almost no head no lacing.  Aroma was of funk stright up barnyard and sourness.  Flavor was much the same.  refreshing beer but not as good as i wanted it to be.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2006 Bottle (750ml).  Shared with blankboy, GregClow andI tupalev, my bottle via trade with Boutip.  Murky red-ruby, smallish white head.  Smells like a sour lambic - funky and fruity, sour, oaky - nice - fruit comes out more on warming, nice grape character on warming.  Solid body, very astringent, sour and carbonated.  Nice - very drinkable.

Sometimes you open up a bottle you had intended for a "landmark" rating just because it is a beautiful day and the mood hits you.  This is one of those times.  2003 bottling.  Medium brown with a strong purple streak, very little head.  Aroma is straight horseblanket, cheddar, and sour funk.  Signature Cantillon, and in my opinion, fantastic.  The usual piercing sourness is followed by somewhat more cheddar than I normally find in Cantillons brews, with a tannic finish that evokes grape skins.  Great stuff.

I was hoping for more, but this was pretty straight forward, simple, and typical, although decent. The pour was ruby red, light haziness, weak initial head, no retention, zero lacing. The aroma was brett, barnyard funk, horseblankets, tart fruits. The flavor followed suit, but wasnt complex and didnt really feature grapes or any one single fruit. Mouthfeel was flat, acidic. Again, not that distinctive, but refreshing for a summer day at the beach.

Its so amazing to come from drinking Miller Lite to drinking a Lambic like this. Ipaid 25 bucks for this bottle,poured it in the glass and got the aroma of horse sweat and field hay aroma,and thinking this is wonderful. Taste was horse blanket and sour grape skins,very astringent,just the most interesting taste Ive had in a long time,worth 20 + bucks,? get a friend to buy it first
bottle. murky amber color with a thin pink head. berry aroma with notes of wood. bit yeasty.

The sweatiest cantillon so far. Aroma is wet hay and sheep, wit fruity cherry hints and some grassy hop too. Taste is unblended with nutty characters and the grapes are stubtle but there. Intresting but not my fav from cantillon.

Bottle:  Courtesy of Sprinkle via trade.   Sour tart aroma with light grape and moderate woodiness.  Pours a cloudy orangish-pink with a minimal white head that fades to nothing very quickly.  Outstanding sour tart flavors with just a hint of grape in the background.  Nice dry woody finish.  One of my favorite Cantillons.

Bottle 2005.  Dark red beer with a lightish head.  The aroma is quite vinous, warm, spiced and cherry/strawberry fruits.  The flavour is quite sour and bitter with a warm fermented mouth feel.  Overall a reasonable beer.

0,375 l bottle. Yellow-red-brown color, no head. Sharp and sulfury aroma with notes of grapes and currants. Sour, sulfury and leathery flavor with grapes and tobacco. Mouth drying finish with grapes and lots of aciid!

Brown bottle, purchased on January 30, 2006, best before 12/2009; eye: red with salmonish reflections, rosish head made up of small champagne-like bubbles, head falls rapidly to leave a ring around the glass, clear, light effervescence; nose: sour, "fresh", wine, cherry, citrusy, green apples, vanilla, balsamic vinegar; mouth: starts with its sour side, followed by cherries and grapes, some tartness, finale of a good length with lots of green apples and a resurgence of sourness at the very end, lost of saliva produced, lightly sweet, midly sour, medium body, free-flowing, nice carbonation; overall: enjoyed quite a bit

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 750 ml, acheté le 30 janvier 2006, meilleure avant 12/2009; oeil : rouge avec des reflets saumon, mousse teintée de rose formée de petites bulles rappelant le champagne, mousse qui saffaisse rapidement pour laisser un petite anneau autour du verre, claire, légère effervescence; nez : sure, frais, vin, cerises, citrique, pommes vertes, vanille, vinaigre balsamique; bouche : commence par son côté sure, suivi de cerises, puis apparation de son côté aigrelet et acidique, finale de bonne durée en pommes vertes avec une recrudescence surette à la toute fin, beaucoup de salive en bouche, légèrement sucrée, moyennement sure, corps moyen, coulante, bonne carbonatation; en résumé : bien aimé
Bottle ølbaren, i got the last glas, Mette strated the bottle without me. Deep red color. Juice of red berries, sweet, sour, grapes, a dry sour finish.
Bottle. Pours a lovely hazy reddish colour with a slightly pinkish head. Sweet malty and sour barnyard aroma. Fruity malty flavor with hints of barnyard and grapes. Sweet malty fruity finish.

Rosy top in the look here, deeper burgundy beneath, under absolutely no head...par for style, though...

Aroma: bracing, yet invigorating, a blast of cherries and grape, twisted by sour...musty, rank, and deep...liking it...a deep well, dominated by fruit. Delectable.

Taste it, already! Oooo! Weeee! Owww! Bold, huge, fat puckeration,...ooo, ooo, ooo! Takes hold of the mouth and doesnt let go! A blend of dark fruits, cherries, and berries, and grapes. Luscious. Sour and flavorful. Mellows a touch, gets easy as we go, gets easier to take..

Not for everyone, but a particular treat for demanding palates, constant play on the tongue that is rewarding for some, punishing for others.

Hard to compare this to anything else on earth. Far beyond any other lambic, a definitive sui generis classic. 

2004 bottling. too young? whos to say. worth the $33 spent? probably...
Light hazy reddish colour with a thin pink head. Light tart fruity aroma with notes of wood. Tart fruity flavor with a light yeasty note.

Pours a solid clear red with a thin pink head. Clean, tart Lambic aroma with only the faintest grape influence. Sour, woody, slightly tannic and with some ashy notes. Finishes dry. A bit thin in body. The flavors work quite well. I got this at the brewery, dragged it all over Belgium and France, finally enjoyed it today.

750 ml bottle, purchased  in Belgium and shared by Vac and zug4abby - thanks you two!  Pours a clear deep ruby color with a small pinkish head.  Dry champagne aroma, wet wool, some sweat and funk.  Flavor is complex and hard to describe, dry and funky, with notes of grape juice bereft of sugars, champagne, wood and tannins.  Light to medium body, fizzy and creamy carbonation.

<!-- i -->Bottled 0,375 ltr<!-- /i --><!-- br -->
Cherry red, decent creamy mostly vanishing reddish head. Earthy farmhouse aroma with some strawberries, grape there too. Sour (of course), quite red wine -like grape flavors burst from the background. Not really so much different than their Kriek, but this one lends towards more winous flavor palette.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2006 Purchased at the Cantillon Brewery, BE. Beautiful fruity, tart aroma and crystal clear cherry-juice color with a pink head. Very dry and lively beer with distinct red-wine flavors with just a hint of actual grape. Very complex and challenging beer, but also very rewarding.
Draft: Dark reddish/purple, winish aroma, Tart, hints of merlot, acidic. Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2006 (Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm 27 April) - Beautiful clear red body, no head; Even though this again is the strange mix of wine and lambic, this one has an unusual clarity. The lambic character is very clear and it is spiced with the elegance of the grapes.
